fields.headline: Trump says transition ‘going so smoothly’
fields.bodyText: Potential members of the Donald Trump administration came and went at Trump tower all day long, but a week after the election, only two names had been announced: strategist Steve Bannon and chief of staff Reince Priebus. Transition in chaos Former congressman Mike Rogers, who was booted from the process, told CNN: “There’s some confusion going on about a chain of command coming out of New York.” The comment won praise for restraint. US as haven for Jews has changed It might take just a minute to catch up on the latest campaign news. But good journalism takes time and costs money. If you like the Guardian’s politics coverage, please consider joining us by becoming a member for only $6.99 a month. Thanks for reading! Become a Guardian member You don’t form a federal government overnight and these are very serious issues, very serious appointments, very serious considerations. – Kellyanne Conway After hosting the vice-president-elect and his wife for lunch at his official residence, Joe Biden said: “No administration is ready on day one ... But I’m confident on day one everything will be in good hands and they’ll be able to handle everything...” American campaigns are pretty robust. I think a lot of Americans don’t realize we’ve had a lot of elections like this in the past. I’m thinking of 1824. – Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell Trump surrogate Kellyanne Conway would not deny that Trump had requested security clearances for his son-in-law, Jared Kushner. “It’s appropriate for whoever’s going to get the presidential daily briefing to have a security clearance,” she said. Who is Jared Kushner? Bernie Sanders called on Trump to rescind his appointment of Bannon, whom Sanders referred to as “a racist individual”. Sanders announced “a major speech” about Trump to take place tonight. The golden letters of Trump’s name were taken off multiple residential properties in New York City today after tenants complained about living in Trump-branded buildings. Trump’s plan for decorating the White House is yet to be announced. I let him know that so many New Yorkers were fearful and that more had to be done to show that this country can heal, that people be respected … Even though I have very real differences with the president-elect, he is a New Yorker, I do think he loves this city. – New York City mayor Bill de Blasio, after meeting with Trump
